Message.Title: Romney is a COWARD...
Message.Msg: Let's call a spade a spade: Romney is a coward. He's shown it from his youth, and still puts it on display every day. It's not the draft deferments by themselves--lots of people did that. It's that he participated in demonstrations supporting the draft, saying that others should fight and die, but not him. It's the bullying incident with the kid at the prep school. It's his unwillingness to confront and denounce ugly statements made by those within his own party. It's guiding his sons around the military, while encouraging the country to participate in unnecessary military actions. A true chicken hawk in every respect--with the emphasis on CHICKEN. (Comparing him to Obama or Clinton would be silly; Obama came of draft age when there was no longer a draft and we weren't involved in a war, while Romney opted out during the height of hostilities--a war that he openly supported. And at least Clinton wasn't a hypocrite about the war.) Those who believe that our national leader should be a true cringing, yellow-bellied coward should support Romney for president.

Message.Title: Are you concerned with declining triangle formation?
Message.Msg: Short term problem is a triangle formation that has declining tops since May and base a bit lower than 25 that is about to break any week now the way it is going. The typical theory suggests a drop sub 25 for good. I think if that happens it opens the door for 21 worse case total breakdown in the traditional triangle formation high to base to low sense (29-25-21) but its too cheap in value for intel to drop even sub 24. In any case i dont buy TA patterns very much in general as a lot of it is charlatan bs (eg Elliot wave theory give me a break) but those that indicate declining tops and common base are kind of rational to interpret as reduced ability to rally and improved stress on the support level base until it finally breaks down. Intel is in a bad spot in terms of all the attacks received left and right and global economic stupidity of leaders to create solutions that focus on growth instead of austerity without a future. Intel itself is doing a great job as a company given all the stress. For near term i view the pattern as risk unless we could rally over 26 very soon again to break the pattern. If we rally here and dont even go as high as 26 and then drop again prepare for very bad drop. I dont like how this looks and i am objective, i have hedged sub 25 with puts bought over 26 but i have uncapped core position if we rally and break out. However i remain skeptical here. In any other case the drop sub 25 today would be a buy signal by the way but the triangle stress is putting things in a different perspective near term. Bottom line i am not very happy near term here even if valuation is a steal. Probably a chance to sell puts short if it gets ugly below 25. I still see Intel over 29 later this year.

Message.Title: Intel vindicated by TSMC/ARM announcement
Message.Msg: ARM and TSMC are teaming up to optimize next-generation 64-bit ARM cores for FinFET process technology. And that must be leaving Intel feeling rather smug. After all, it completely validates what the chip behemoth said at its investor day -- in both Paul Otellini's and Brian Krzanich's presentations – that Intel is a good four years ahead of its closest foundry competition. Indeed, as my colleague Peter Clarke notes over in his article, the collaboration between the Taiwanese manufacturer and ARM isn’t even expected to yield introductory results much before the second half of 2015, and that is probably an optimistic bet. Furthermore, the announcement serves to show just how far behind ARM will be in terms of making any sort of serious impact on the server market. ARM has repeatedly said it would have a serious server market offering by 2014, and would be able to capture meaningful market share within two to three years, but this latest announcement throws a whole lot of cold water on that notion. If ARM’s latest press release represents the current state of things, it means 64-bit V8 architecture on FinFET process tech is roughly three and a half years away at best, giving Intel ample time to work out all its current kinks and remain far out ahead of its competition. The announcement also means TSMC may be re-setting its strategy for FinFet (tri-gate), after it had previously told the market it would target second generation 20nm. Today’s press release reads like the manufacturer has had to adjust the plan to sub-20nm, though whether TSMC jumped or was pushed is easily debatable. “There’s no doubt that based on current plans of record, Intel’s way ahead of any other company with regard to FinFET deployment,” said industry analyst Nathan Brookwood of Insight64. “They’re shipping millions of devices with 3-D transistors today, but TSMC and Globalfoundries don’t plan to introduce the technology until their 14nm nodes, at least four years away with regard to volume production. I hear both companies want to pull that technology in, but that’s where things stand today.” http://www.eetimes.com/electronics-blogs/other/4390922/Intel-vindicated-by-TSMC-ARM-announcement

Topic.Title: Intel vindicated by TSMC/ARM announcement

Message.Msg: ARM has repeatedly said it would have a serious server market offering by 2014, and would be able to capture meaningful market share within two to three years, but this latest announcement throws a whole lot of cold water on that notion. If ARM’s latest press release represents the current state of things, it means 64-bit V8 architecture on FinFET process tech is roughly three and a half years away at best, giving Intel ample time to work out all its current kinks and remain far out ahead of its competition. [If only these two paragraphs could be shrunk down to a single phrase that could be tattooed on Wall Street's forehead in mirror image...]

Topic.Title: TI's earns and outlook not good for INTC

Message.Msg: Intel has made their forecasts and has factored all this into its forecasts. Intel has met or exceeded current quarter forecast for the last two years. What new light does the TI earnings show that Intel was not aware of last week? Q2Q, TI saw increases in Analog divisions but their wireless business evaporated. TI is expecting a -20% impact from buying National Semi to Q3 revenues. They are seeing customer caution and its impact on orders late in the quarter. Intel has a slightly differnt product mix and Intel has no hit to earnings from absorbing a purchase like National Semi. "TI revenue in the second quarter was about as we had expected," said Rich Templeton, TI's chairman, president and CEO. "Our Analog and Embedded Processing segments grew sequentially, while our Wireless segment declined. http://investor.ti.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=694362 Embedded revenue was down q2q by -15% Wireless revenue was down q2q by -39% (ARM CPU)

Topic.Title: Hey Alexander --- what is the dollar amount of the ...

Message.Msg: Good job, Alexander. Perhaps you are actually related to Alexander Hamilton after all, but you acquired your family name through an unfortunate sort of romantic liason somewhere back there in the family tree? So I guess one could say that 832 million is chump change to Intel, but bear in mind that is just the current projection of the unfunded obligations --- that these things tend to get worse over time as the plan administrators either can't meet their projections on portfolio returns or (perhaps worse) they end up chasing yield by getting snookered into buying crap like mortgage backed securities in 2007. (I am not suggesting Intel is or will ever be doing stuff like this, I just think it's interesting that the LIBOR fixing was another part of the scheme to create a market for the "financial innovation" by forcing pension funds to seek higher returns in what later became known as "toxic assets". P.T. Barnum's estimate as to the birth rat of suckers was way too low IMO.)

Topic.Title: Intel vindicated by TSMC/ARM announcement

Message.Msg: TSMC plate is more than full: FinFet EUV and 450 mm - 3 major changes pretty much at the same time. They will have to do FinFet and EUV on 300mm but by that time 450 mm might be ready - IOW "shortly" they would be forced to make a move to 450mm. TSMC is reactive and proactive Intel will eventually start using EUV @ 10nm; me thinks Intel will first scale up to 450 mm

Message.Title: Eat your heart out TSMC...
Message.Msg: So, while TSMC and everyone else is sweating out 28/32nm, Intel is actually DEMOLITIONING 32nm fabs!! Not upgradng, not mothballing....Intel is throwing 32nm in the trash can! Amazing. Glen Yeung – Citigroup Inc. Got it. All right, thanks. And as a follow up, maybe for Stacy, looking at the gross margin guidance and looking at your reconciliation in the printed commentary, it sounded like the only negative impact to gross margins in Q3 would be these other cost of sales, and I wonder if you could just explain what’s going on in there? Stacy J. Smith Sure. What’s going on with other cost of sales in Q3 as we are finding some opportunities to take some 32-nanometer capacity offline. They’re relatively small today, but it’s just a result of the lower demand expectations on the year. And so we are taking some of those factories off and so you will see a little bit of demolition costs and some of those things that flows through other cost of sales. And, yeah, it’s not huge, it’s between half a point and a point, but it’s a bit of an offset in gross margin in the third quarter.

Message.Title: Romney is a COWARD!...
Message.Msg: Message from a PATRIOT: I am a Viet Nam vet. My lottery number was 156. I had been deferred before the lottery because I was attending college, not only to get an education, but to stay out of being cannon fodder for the military. I had already lost two good high school buddies to the war, and saw three more come back raging addicts, so I had a great deal of fear and loathing about going to fight a useless war. My name came up on a waiting list for the Air Force Reserve when the lottery was at 154, so I jumped at the chance to join the Reserves. My mom sent me my draft notice while I was at Basic Training in Texas. I still had to fight the war out of a C-130 Herc and a C-141 T-tail Bug Sucker (C-141 Star lifter…both cargo aircraft, one out of MAC; Military Airlift Command, and the 130 out of TAC, Tactical Air Command) Out of TAC, I saw combat. I know of all sorts of tactics used by lots of well connected rich people to make sure their sons got out of the draft, and if I had had the opportunity to avoid going to Nam, I would have jumped at the chance, but I was part of the 99%, so I had to serve. A lot of guys I served with were of the same opinion, but we all served our country, and served it well. I am proud to say I was in the Military today. The resentment I see in the above article about Romney being “privileged” is a correct one. I only saw rich preppies whose fathers were well connected get into “closed” reserve units that were never called to serve, while the majority of us “99%er’s” had to serve and die for a war that everyone knew we were going to lose. What is so disgusting about Romney is his shrilling for a stronger draft knowing he won’t have to serve, that is unforgivable, despicable, vile, and cruel. To call for a war with Iran, not knowing what that really means is to infect our democracy with a cancer of warmongering to line the pockets of the .01% with even more money, greed and control, at the cost of blood and treasure that this county can ill afford. I have watched this country get divided into the “haves”, and “have nots”, and the line is becoming more defined as we progress in this election season. My fear is the election of the GOP with control of both houses of the legislature and the White House. Our doom as a democracy will be sealed if that happens, and Romney is the tip of that spear of doom. His support of a stronger draft, without his own sacrifice or those of his children speaks volumes about his lack of leadership. He is a coward and has no right whatsoever to call himself a patriot, let alone an American. He needs to perform an unnatural sexual act upon himself (instead of the more colorful expression). He is unfit to even serve as dog catcher.

Topic.Title: Romney is a COWARD!...

Message.Msg: The horserace remains tight In the presidential horserace, Obama leads Romney by six percentage points among registered voters, 49 percent to 43 percent. That’s a slight change – within the margin of error – from last month’s poll, which showed Obama ahead by three points, 47 percent to 44 percent. Read the full poll here (.pdf) In a smaller sample of registered voters living in 12 battleground states (Colorado, Florida, Iowa, Michigan, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Mexico, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia and Wisconsin), the incumbent president’s lead over Romney is eight points, 49 to 41, which is essentially unchanged from June.

Message.Title: And you though t the boys in Chicago would be nice to Romney? HAA
Message.Msg: They are going to go negative and make Romney into a clown. Negative views on the rise But what did change was an increase in negative views about both Obama and Romney. The president’s favorable/unfavorable score in the poll is 49 percent to 43 percent, a slight change from June when it was 47 percent to 38 percent. Moreover, 33 percent view Obama very positively, while 32 percent view him very negatively – which is his highest “very negative” number in poll. By comparison, Romney’s overall favorable/unfavorable score is 35 percent to 40 percent, with 24 percent viewing him “very” negatively – also his highest mark here. Read the full poll here (.pdf) In fact, Romney would be the first GOP presumptive presidential nominee since 1996 to head into his nominating convention with a net-negative favorable/unfavorable score. In 1996, Bob Dole’s score was 39 percent to 36 percent; in 2000, George W. Bush’s was 52 percent to 32 percent; and in 2008, John McCain’s was 42 percent to 30 percent.

Topic.Title: QCOM QC VS Medfield

Message.Msg: I would take these numbers with a pinch of salt since these benchmarks favor the quad core Krait. Once Intel comes out with its own dual-core chip targeting tablets, I'm sure it will level up. Medfield's showing is impressive considering that it's doing all this with just one core. (With four cores, the Qualcomm chip would obviously run down its battery in no time in the real world). Slightly later, when Intel comes out with its own architectural revision at 22nm (forget the name) then we'll really get to see how the architectures match up. Krait after all is one generation beyond ARM's A9 so it's unfair to compare it with more or less last generation Medfield. As Intel's Mike Bell himself said, the instruction set has no role to play in this match up so it really does boil down to how well they lay out the gates. Intel's engineers are recognized experts in this.

Message.Title: Et tu Apple?
Message.Msg: Every couple months we get some random punk come on here and explain to us the new world order. Intel is dead and tablets and phones are all we'll ever need in the future. It's a zero sum game, every new tablet or phone sold is one less PC sold. Like they exist in a world where they are mutually exclusive. A person can't own a PC and a tablet and/or smartphone. Today, Apple announced a miss on expectations. Yes they sold 17 million tablets, but came up a little light on phones. People are waiting for the iPhone5 they tell us. Just a few short years ago Steve Jobs was the Barry Bonds of home runs for Apple back in the height of juicing. But, even before he died Apple was starting to run out of home runs. As you may recall Steve Jobs died the day after the iPhone 4s. An appropriate time to go in my opinion, the phone didn't bring anything new to the game, unless you consider Siri to be noteworthy. The days of Apple bringing a sense of wonder to the world with a new, innovative product that makes teenagers clean out their bank accounts seem to be over. All they can bank on right now is that there are enough customers with too many apps and song loaded on their phones to want to do a paradigm shift. They are waiting around for something brilliant. This has to be something that can be relevant for one full year, and then slightly modified for the next year like the iPhone 4s. Here's my point, even with 100 billion dollars sitting in a vault and untold thousands of brilliant people on the payroll I don't think Apple can keep the safe distance between them and their competition. In a couple of months we'll know for certain but I'm feeling by looking at the releases of the iPhone 4s and iPad(3) that Apple can't set the bar high enough anymore. My take on what really happened with Apple today is that when someone recently wanted to buy their first Smartphone they went to their local wireless store to look at the 4S that everybody told them to check out. While they were their they noticed a small crowd of people standing around the Samsung phones. "Let me see that!" And there is one less Apple sale. It doesn't have to happen every time, just enough to become a problem. Apple is going to sell an amazing amount of iPhone5's because they have enough loyal customers who want to buy it now matter how good or bad it is. This can help with their numbers for a quarter or two. But this miss you saw today with Apple, expect more in the future as their segment turns generic.
LOL, Lucy prefers 50 percent losses and telling everyone THEY are dumb instead of 25% gains, dividends and humility. Whatever floats the lil' guy's boat.
